title.narrative: Transfer of Relief to Afghans through Cash in Emergency (TRACE)

description.narrative: Services Provided and Location: IRC proposes to assist 4,000 households (60% of which will be new IDPs) across Helmand and Nangarhar provinces in the event of conflict by utilizing cash transfers of AFN 8,000 ($116) for NFIs to 3000 (out of 4000) households and cash transfer of 75$ for food to all 4000 affected families. The amount of cash distributed for food and NFIs will be delivered as a one off payment and disbursements are in line with the industry standard practice of the cluster group and is comparable to practice by other INGOs in Afghanistan including DRC and NRC. Cash can often be delivered more quickly than in-kind commodities and though the provision of cash alone is not always sufficient, it is eminently possible to link cash transfer programs to other forms of support. IRC has completed a Needs Assessment, a Market Assessment, a Payment Mechanism Assessment and a Risk Assessment that will inform cash distributions. The IRC team will utilize vetted financial services providers (e.g. cellphone companies, banks and Hawala agents) to ensure that cash reaches beneficiaries in a timely and secure manner. All cash distributions are supervised and audited by multiple team and community members, to ensure that all community members’ needs are considered, including those with significantly lower social profiles. After determining eligibility and distributing cash, IRC will monitor and follow-up with household visits to ensure that the most vulnerable have been targeted. IRC will evaluate beneficiaries via sample monitoring and make use of other techniques to elicit feedback including hotlines, suggestion/complaint boxes, dedicated email address, SMS line and community liaisons. On-site feedback will be elicited directly through a combination of open community meetings, focus groups, satisfaction surveys, and community assessment and monitoring data. Based on established emergency response procedures, IRC will conduct joint emergency needs and market assessments to determine NFI and food needs, including whether cash distribution is appropriate and the functioning of local markets. A Market assessment has been conducted in the second week of June 2016 and has been shared with the Emergency Shelter and NFI cluster, and the IRC field teams have conducted an updated assessment in the target provinces to verify costs for Food and NFI commodities. The IRC will conduct a conclusive assessment at the beginning of this project that will assist in selecting vendors that can handle increased demand of materials. Cash amounts to be distributed will be based on the results of such assessments. IRC will coordinate with other agencies to avoid duplication and ensure the most vulnerable communities are being assisted. Beneficiary families will be identified during joint assessments in consultation with community representatives, including CDCs/Shuras.
